question: So he turned his horse and brought her also [MASK] again.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: look again for thy bride,   For sheâs not the true one that sits by thy side.â  Then he looked down, and saw that the blood streamed so much from the shoe, that her white stockings were quite red.
next_sentence: âThis is not the true bride,â said he to the father; âhave you no other daughters?â âNo,â said he; âthere is only a little dirty Ashputtel here, the child of my first wife; I am sure she cannot be the bride.â The prince told him to send her.

question: Then the girl told her father all that had [MASK].
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: All night long they walked, and it was morning before they reached the mill.
next_sentence: The day came that had been fixed for the marriage.

question: At last he [MASK]: âOh, you wretched beard-cleaner, you piebald fool, you hungry mouse-hunter, what can you be thinking of?
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: How are you getting on in these hard times?â The fox, full of all kinds of arrogance, looked at the cat from head to foot, and for a long time did not know whether he would give any answer or not.
next_sentence: Have you the cheek to ask how I am getting on?

question: When she went home the mouse inquired: âAnd what was the child [MASK]? â âHalf-done, â answered the cat.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: âNothing ever seems so good as what one keeps to oneself,â said she, and was quite satisfied with her dayâs work.
next_sentence: âHalf-done!

question: The kingâs son wanted to climb up to her, and looked for the door of the [MASK], but none was to be found.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: This was Rapunzel, who in her solitude passed her time in letting her sweet voice resound.
next_sentence: He rode home, but the singing had so deeply touched his heart, that every day he went out into the forest and listened to it.

question: We must shift for ourselves, and yet we cannot [MASK]!
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: âOut with you, you idle, good-for-nothing creatures!â cried they; âwe cannot find food for you any longer; you are big enough, and can provide for yourselves.â But the poor young ravens lay upon the ground, flapping their wings, and crying: âOh, what helpless chicks we are!
next_sentence: What can we do, but lie here and starve?â So the good young fellow alighted and killed his horse with his sword, and gave it to them for food.

question: Now we shall never have anything more to wish for as [MASK] as we live.â âI donât know how that may be, â said she; ânever is a long time.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: what a fine thing it is to be king!
next_sentence: I am king, it is true; but I begin to be tired of that, and I think I should like to be emperor.â âAlas, wife!

question: Cat-skin was brought again before the king, but she still told him that she was only fit to have [MASK] and shoes thrown at her head.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Whilst the cook was above stairs, she got the golden necklace and dropped it into the soup; then it was brought to the king, who ate it, and it pleased him as well as before; so he sent for the cook, who was again forced to tell him that Cat-skin had cooked it.
next_sentence: But when the king had ordered a feast to be got ready for the third time, it happened just the same as before.

question: This touched the old kingâs heart, and he thought his son might still be guiltless, and [MASK] to his court, âO that my son were still alive!
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Some time after, three grand embassies came to the old kingâs court, with rich gifts of gold and precious stones for his youngest son; now all these were sent from the three kings to whom he had lent his sword and loaf of bread, in order to rid them of their enemy and feed their people.
next_sentence: how it grieves me that I had him killed!â âHe is still alive,â said the huntsman; âand I am glad that I had pity on him, but let him go in peace, and brought home his royal coat.â At this the king was overwhelmed with joy, and made it known throughout all his kingdom, that if his son would come back to his court he would forgive him.

question: âNot wretch enough yet! â said the sparrow; âthy cruelty shall cost thee thy life yet! â and [MASK] she flew.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: âUnlucky wretch that I am!â cried the carter; for he saw that the corn was almost all gone.
next_sentence: The carter seeing that he had thus lost all that he had, went down into his kitchen; and was still not sorry for what he had done, but sat himself angrily and sulkily in the chimney corner.

question: One evening, as they were thus [MASK] comfortably together, someone knocked at the door as if he wished to be let in.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: And close by them lay a lamb upon the floor, and behind them upon a perch sat a white dove with its head hidden beneath its wings.
next_sentence: The mother said: âQuick, Rose-red, open the door, it must be a traveller who is seeking shelter.â Rose-red went and pushed back the bolt, thinking that it was a poor man, but it was not; it was a bear that stretched his broad, black head within the door.

question: âBefore you receive my daughter, and the [MASK] of my kingdom, â said he to him, âyou must perform one more heroic deed.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: The little tailor demanded of the king the promised reward; he, however, repented of his promise, and again bethought himself how he could get rid of the hero.
next_sentence: In the forest roams a unicorn which does great harm, and you must catch it first.â âI fear one unicorn still less than two giants.

question: For a long time she did not know that she had ever had any [MASK]; for her father and mother took care not to speak of them before her: but one day by chance she heard the people about her speak of them.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Sorry as he was to see his wish so fulfilled, he did not know how what was done could be undone, and comforted himself as well as he could for the loss of his seven sons with his dear little daughter, who soon became stronger and every day more beautiful.
next_sentence: âYes,â said they, âshe is beautiful indeed, but still âtis a pity that her brothers should have been lost for her sake.â Then she was much grieved, and went to her father and mother, and asked if she had any brothers, and what had become of them.

question: âWhen everything is [MASK] up one has some peace, â said she to herself, and well filled and fat she did not return home till night.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Half-done!â answered the mouse, âthey are such odd names, they make me very thoughtful.â âYou sit at home,â said the cat, âin your dark-grey fur coat and long tail, and are filled with fancies, thatâs because you do not go out in the daytime.â During the catâs absence the mouse cleaned the house, and put it in order, but the greedy cat entirely emptied the pot of fat.
next_sentence: The mouse at once asked what name had been given to the third child.

question: You shall at once go into your coffin again, â and he took him up, [MASK] him into it, and shut the lid.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Then said the youth, âSee, little cousin, have I not warmed you?â The dead man, however, got up and cried: âNow will I strangle you.â  âWhat!â said he, âis that the way you thank me?
next_sentence: Then came the six men and carried him away again.

question: He travelled about a long time in search of it and came at last to a [MASK] forest, through which he went on walking for fourteen days and still could not find a way out.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: He rose up without delay, eager to start on his way and to reach the castle of Stromberg, but he had no idea in which direction he ought to go.
next_sentence: Once more the night came on, and worn out he lay down under a bush and fell asleep.

question: When it became known that the old fox was [MASK], suitors presented themselves.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Mrs Fox went up to her room, shut herself in, and her maid, Miss Cat, sat by the fire, and did the cooking.
next_sentence: The maid heard someone standing at the house-door, knocking.

question: When it [MASK] to her turn to sing, she stepped back, until at last she was the only one left, and then she could not refuse.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: When the faithful maiden heard of this, she grew so sad that she thought her heart would break, and she would not go thither, but the other girls came and took her.
next_sentence: But when she began her song, and it reached Rolandâs ears, he sprang up and cried: âI know the voice, that is the true bride, I will have no other!â Everything he had forgotten, and which had vanished from his mind, had suddenly come home again to his heart.

question: Then he [MASK] his son and told him that he had only a false bride; for that she was merely a waiting-maid, while the true bride stood by.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: And it was very lucky for her that she did so, for when she had done the king ordered royal clothes to be put upon her, and gazed on her with wonder, she was so beautiful.
next_sentence: And the young king rejoiced when he saw her beauty, and heard how meek and patient she had been; and without saying anything to the false bride, the king ordered a great feast to be got ready for all his court.

question: He had two richly laden ships then [MASK] a voyage upon the seas, in which he had embarked all his wealth, in the hope of making great gains, when the news came that both were lost.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: THE KING OF THE GOLDEN MOUNTAIN  There was once a merchant who had only one child, a son, that was very young, and barely able to run alone.
next_sentence: Thus from being a rich man he became all at once so very poor that nothing was left to him but one small plot of land; and there he often went in an evening to take his walk, and ease his mind of a little of his trouble.

question: But when the [MASK] princess perceived that he was not her equal in birth, she scorned him, and required him first to perform another task.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Full of joy he took it to the king and expected that he would grant him the promised reward.
next_sentence: She went down into the garden and strewed with her own hands ten sacksful of millet-seed on the grass; then she said: âTomorrow morning before sunrise these must be picked up, and not a single grain be wanting.â  The youth sat down in the garden and considered how it might be possible to perform this task, but he could think of nothing, and there he sat sorrowfully awaiting the break of day, when he should be led to death.

question: She went straight to the [MASK], stole to the pot of fat, began to lick at it, and licked the top of the fat off.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: I should like a drop of sweet red christening wine myself.â All this, however, was untrue; the cat had no cousin, and had not been asked to be godmother.
next_sentence: Then she took a walk upon the roofs of the town, looked out for opportunities, and then stretched herself in the sun, and licked her lips whenever she thought of the pot of fat, and not until it was evening did she return home.

question: When therefore the son had been proclaimed king, and the time of mourning was over, he was forced to keep the promise which he had given his father, and caused the kingâs daughter to be asked in [MASK], and she was promised to him.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: The son was in such trouble that he did not think what he was doing, and said: âYes, dear father, your will shall be done,â and thereupon the king shut his eyes, and died.
next_sentence: His first betrothed heard of this, and fretted so much about his faithfulness that she nearly died.

question: The youth wandered on, and after some [MASK] came to a fortress where he begged for a nightâs lodging.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: I will send you to a third master, but if you learn nothing this time also, I will no longer be your father.â The youth remained a whole year with the third master also, and when he came home again, and his father inquired: âMy son, what have you learnt?â he answered: âDear father, I have this year learnt what the frogs croak.â Then the father fell into the most furious anger, sprang up, called his people thither, and said: âThis man is no longer my son, I drive him forth, and command you to take him out into the forest, and kill him.â They took him forth, but when they should have killed him, they could not do it for pity, and let him go, and they cut the eyes and tongue out of a deer that they might carry them to the old man as a token.
next_sentence: âYes,â said the lord of the castle, âif you will pass the night down there in the old tower, go thither; but I warn you, it is at the peril of your life, for it is full of wild dogs, which bark and howl without stopping, and at certain hours a man has to be given to them, whom they at once devour.â The whole district was in sorrow and dismay because of them, and yet no one could do anything to stop this.

question: âAnd you, my [MASK], â said the bridegroom, turning to her, âis there no tale you know?
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: As they sat at the feast, each guest in turn was asked to tell a tale; the bride sat still and did not say a word.
next_sentence: Tell us something.â  âI will tell you a dream, then,â said the bride.

question: âWait, â said he, âI will [MASK] you a little, â and went to the fire and warmed his hand and laid it on the dead manâs face, but he remained cold.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: He felt his face, but it was cold as ice.
next_sentence: Then he took him out, and sat down by the fire and laid him on his breast and rubbed his arms that the blood might circulate again.

question: Then said they: âThere is nothing to be done here, â and they went home and told the cook that they had [MASK] nothing in the forest but a little rose-bush with one rose on it.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: The children, however, were sitting outside the forest, and when they saw from afar the three servants running, Lina said to Fundevogel: âNever leave me, and I will never leave you.â Fundevogel said: âNeither now, nor ever.â Then said Lina: âDo you become a rose-tree, and I the rose upon it.â When the three servants came to the forest, nothing was there but a rose-tree and one rose on it, but the children were nowhere.
next_sentence: Then the old cook scolded and said: âYou simpletons, you should have cut the rose-bush in two, and have broken off the rose and brought it home with you; go, and do it at once.â They had therefore to go out and look for the second time.

question: So he had put forth a [MASK] that whosoever should be able to make her laugh should marry her.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Soon afterwards he came to a city, where a king ruled who had a daughter who was so serious that no one could make her laugh.
next_sentence: When Dummling heard this, he went with his goose and all her train before the kingâs daughter, and as soon as she saw the seven people running on and on, one behind the other, she began to laugh quite loudly, and as if she would never stop.

question: But when he began to walk and to move about, the stones in his stomach [MASK] against each other and rattled.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: When the wolf at length had had his fill of sleep, he got on his legs, and as the stones in his stomach made him very thirsty, he wanted to go to a well to drink.
next_sentence: Then cried he:   âWhat rumbles and tumbles   Against my poor bones?

question: They were both very unhappy, but [MASK] to make the best of things and to remain with one another.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: He picked up the wood, and flew sadly home, and told the mouse all he had seen and heard.
next_sentence: So now the bird set the table, and the mouse looked after the food and, wishing to prepare it in the same way as the sausage, by rolling in and out among the vegetables to salt and butter them, she jumped into the pot; but she stopped short long before she reached the bottom, having already parted not only with her skin and hair, but also with life.

question: [MASK] they brought him a wooden bowl for a few half-pence, out of which he had to eat.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: The young wife scolded him, but he said nothing and only sighed.
next_sentence: They were once sitting thus when the little grandson of four years old began to gather together some bits of wood upon the ground.

question: What a shame to take my [MASK], and give me only a dry cow!
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Then the butcher gave him a flask of ale, saying, âThere, drink and refresh yourself; your cow will give you no milk: donât you see she is an old beast, good for nothing but the slaughter-house?â âAlas, alas!â said Hans, âwho would have thought it?
next_sentence: If I kill her, what will she be good for?

question: In [MASK] of the house there was a court, in which grew a juniper-tree.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: So greatly did they desire to have one, that the wife prayed for it day and night, but still they remained childless.
next_sentence: One winterâs day the wife stood under the tree to peel some apples, and as she was peeling them, she cut her finger, and the blood fell on the snow.

question: When the wolf had appeased his appetite, he [MASK] down again in the bed, fell asleep and began to snore very loud.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: but, grandmother, what a terrible big mouth you have!â  âThe better to eat you with!â  And scarcely had the wolf said this, than with one bound he was out of bed and swallowed up Red-Cap.
next_sentence: The huntsman was just passing the house, and thought to himself: âHow the old woman is snoring!

question: Meantime the master looked to see that the table was properly laid, and took the great knife, wherewith he was going to carve the [MASK], and sharpened it on the steps.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: While she was making the most of it, her master came and cried: âHurry up, Gretel, the guest is coming directly after me!â âYes, sir, I will soon serve up,â answered Gretel.
next_sentence: Presently the guest came, and knocked politely and courteously at the house-door.

question: Now, though it is said that fishes are dumb, he heard them lamenting that they must perish so miserably, and, as he had a kind [MASK], he got off his horse and put the three prisoners back into the water.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: When his request was granted he set out on his way, and one day came to a pond, where he saw three fishes caught in the reeds and gasping for water.
next_sentence: They leapt with delight, put out their heads, and cried to him: âWe will remember you and repay you for saving us!â  He rode on, and after a while it seemed to him that he heard a voice in the sand at his feet.

question: However, the duck, who slept in the open air in the yard, heard them coming, and jumping into the brook which [MASK] close by the inn, soon swam out of their reach.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Early in the morning, before it was quite light, and when nobody was stirring in the inn, Chanticleer awakened his wife, and, fetching the egg, they pecked a hole in it, ate it up, and threw the shells into the fireplace: they then went to the pin and needle, who were fast asleep, and seizing them by the heads, stuck one into the landlordâs easy chair and the other into his handkerchief; and, having done this, they crept away as softly as possible.
next_sentence: An hour or two afterwards the landlord got up, and took his handkerchief to wipe his face, but the pin ran into him and pricked him: then he walked into the kitchen to light his pipe at the fire, but when he stirred it up the eggshells flew into his eyes, and almost blinded him.

question: The same day a customer [MASK] in, and the shoes suited him so well that he willingly paid a price higher than usual for them; and the poor shoemaker, with the money, bought leather enough to make two pairs more.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: He looked at the workmanship; there was not one false stitch in the whole job; all was so neat and true, that it was quite a masterpiece.
next_sentence: In the evening he cut out the work, and went to bed early, that he might get up and begin betimes next day; but he was saved all the trouble, for when he got up in the morning the work was done ready to his hand.

question: Time passed on again, and the [MASK] son too wished to set out into the wide world to seek for the golden bird; but his father would not listen to it for a long while, for he was very fond of his son, and was afraid that some ill luck might happen to him also, and prevent his coming back.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: He met the fox, who gave him the good advice: but when he came to the two inns, his eldest brother was standing at the window where the merrymaking was, and called to him to come in; and he could not withstand the temptation, but went in, and forgot the golden bird and his country in the same manner.
next_sentence: However, at last it was agreed he should go, for he would not rest at home; and as he came to the wood, he met the fox, and heard the same good counsel.

question: âWe will not [MASK] the door, â cried they, âyou are not our mother.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: It was not long before someone knocked at the house-door and called: âOpen the door, dear children; your mother is here, and has brought something back with her for each of you.â But the little kids knew that it was the wolf, by the rough voice.
next_sentence: She has a soft, pleasant voice, but your voice is rough; you are the wolf!â Then the wolf went away to a shopkeeper and bought himself a great lump of chalk, ate this and made his voice soft with it.

question: In a forest of his country lived two giants, who caused great mischief with their robbing, murdering, ravaging, and burning, and no one could approach them without putting himself in danger of [MASK].
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: He sent to the little tailor and caused him to be informed that as he was a great warrior, he had one request to make to him.
next_sentence: If the tailor conquered and killed these two giants, he would give him his only daughter to wife, and half of his kingdom as a dowry, likewise one hundred horsemen should go with him to assist him.

question: They ran up and saw with horror that the [MASK] had seized their old acquaintance the dwarf, and was going to carry him off.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Immediately they heard a loud, piteous cry.
next_sentence: The children, full of pity, at once took tight hold of the little man, and pulled against the eagle so long that at last he let his booty go.

question: So the lazy girl had to go home [MASK] with pitch, and the cock on the well called out as she saw her: âCock-a-doodle-doo!
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: âThat is in return for your services,â said the old woman, and she shut the gate.
next_sentence: Your dirty daughterâs come back to you.â  But, try what she would, she could not get the pitch off and it stuck to her as long as she lived.

question: She again gave him a handful of ducats, but he would not keep them, and [MASK] them to the gardener for playthings for his children.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: He took them to the gardener, and said: âI present them to your children, they can play with them.â The following day the kingâs daughter again called to him that he was to bring her a wreath of field-flowers, and then he went in with it, she instantly snatched at his cap, and wanted to take it away from him, but he held it fast with both hands.
next_sentence: On the third day things went just the same; she could not get his cap away from him, and he would not have her money.

question: But when the son looked at the [MASK], he thought it a great pity to put the leathern saddle upon it.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: All went right, and the groom lay snoring with his hand upon the golden saddle.
next_sentence: âI will give him the good one,â said he; âI am sure he deserves it.â As he took up the golden saddle the groom awoke and cried out so loud, that all the guards ran in and took him prisoner, and in the morning he was again brought before the court to be judged, and was sentenced to die.

question: As she was very tired, she [MASK] herself down in the hollow of a tree and soon fell asleep: and there she slept on till it was midday.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Then she threw herself upon Heaven for help in her need, and went away, and journeyed on the whole night, till at last she came to a large wood.
next_sentence: Now as the king to whom the wood belonged was hunting in it, his dogs came to the tree, and began to snuff about, and run round and round, and bark.

question: With these he departed, but he cared nothing for the gold [MASK].
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: He wanted to run out, but she held him by the arm, and gave him a handful of ducats.
next_sentence: He took them to the gardener, and said: âI present them to your children, they can play with them.â The following day the kingâs daughter again called to him that he was to bring her a wreath of field-flowers, and then he went in with it, she instantly snatched at his cap, and wanted to take it away from him, but he held it fast with both hands.

question: But the time was long to him, and he looked at the reflection of his face on the [MASK] of the water.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: âI will allow you to watch by it once more, but if this happens for the third time then the well is polluted and you can no longer remain with me.â  On the third day, the boy sat by the well, and did not stir his finger, however much it hurt him.
next_sentence: And as he still bent down more and more while he was doing so, and trying to look straight into the eyes, his long hair fell down from his shoulders into the water.

question: And as they were so weary that their legs would carry them no longer, they lay down beneath a [MASK] and fell asleep.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: They walked the whole night and all the next day too from morning till evening, but they did not get out of the forest, and were very hungry, for they had nothing to eat but two or three berries, which grew on the ground.
next_sentence: It was now three mornings since they had left their fatherâs house.

question: When the wolf had satisfied his appetite he took himself off, laid himself down under a tree in the green [MASK] outside, and began to sleep.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: The youngest, who was in the clock-case, was the only one he did not find.

question: The dwarf sprang up in a fright, but he could not reach his [MASK], for the bear was already close.

title: Grimms' Fairy Tales

question: They found the ashes scattered by the [MASK], but the peas and lentils had sprouted, and grown sufficiently above the ground, to guide them in the moonlight along the path.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl
title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: But God helped her, so that she passed safely over them, and then she and the old woman went upstairs, opened the door, and hastened as fast as they could from the murderersâ den.

question: Now the [MASK] king happened just then to have nothing else to do; so he amused himself by sitting at his kitchen window, looking at what was going on; and he saw her in the courtyard.

title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: There was great joy at their coming, and the prince flew to meet them, and lifted the maid from her horse, thinking she was the one who was to be his wife; and she was led upstairs to the royal chamber; but the true princess was told to stay in the court below.
next_sentence: As she looked very pretty, and too delicate for a waiting-maid, he went up into the royal chamber to ask the bride who it was she had brought with her, that was thus left standing in the court below.

question: So on they went till they [MASK] to a rapid stream.

prev_sentence: âYes; but you must get up behind, or my horses will not be able to draw you.â Then the fox got up behind; and presently the wolf, the bear, the goat, and all the beasts of the wood, came and climbed upon the hearse.
next_sentence: âHow shall we get over?â said Chanticleer.

question: When he came to the house and went inside, the old [MASK] met him, and said, âPoor man!

title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: I know even now that you will take something from the woman and be unable to save me.â The man assured her again that he would on no account touch a thing to eat or drink.

question: [MASK] the woman served up four different things, roast meat, salad, cakes, and wine.

title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: The peasant ate it, and lay down with his skin beside him, and the woman thought: âHe is tired and has gone to sleep.â In the meantime came the parson; the millerâs wife received him well, and said: âMy husband is out, so we will have a feast.â The peasant listened, and when he heard them talk about feasting he was vexed that he had been forced to make shift with a slice of bread and cheese.
next_sentence: Just as they were about to sit down and eat, there was a knocking outside.

question: âDo that likewise, â said the giant, âif you have strength.â âIs that all? â said the tailor, âthat is childâs play with us! â and put his hand into his pocket, brought out the soft cheese, and pressed it until the liquid [MASK] out of it.

question: The little tailor [MASK] his game again, picked out the biggest stone, and threw it with all his might on the breast of the first giant.

question: She [MASK], âGo farther into the wood until you come to a house, wherein lives an old woman; she will offer you food and drink, but you must not take of either; if you do, you will fall into a deep sleep, and will not be able to help me.

question: They were all drunk, and paid no [MASK] to her cries and lamentations.

question: Your pig may [MASK] you into a scrape.

question: After this he went back to the castle, where he [MASK] everything he wanted.

title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: âI have three tiresome beasts here,â said the other; âif you will take them, give them food and room, and treat them as I tell you, I will pay you whatever you ask.â âWith all my heart,â said the miller; âbut how shall I treat them?â Then the huntsman said, âGive the old one stripes three times a day and hay once; give the next (who was the servant-maid) stripes once a day and hay three times; and give the youngest (who was the beautiful lady) hay three times a day and no stripesâ: for he could not find it in his heart to have her beaten.
next_sentence: Some days after, the miller came to him and told him that the old ass was dead; âThe other two,â said he, âare alive and eat, but are so sorrowful that they cannot last long.â Then the huntsman pitied them, and told the miller to drive them back to him, and when they came, he gave them some of the good salad to eat.

question: Do not forget that we have a christening today! â and running after him he took him by the sleeve, but was also [MASK] fast to it.

question: The peasant made the raven prophesy still more, and said: âThirdly, he [MASK] that there is some salad on the bed.â âThat would be a fine thing! â cried the miller, and went there and found the salad.
source_info: Grimms' Fairy Tales by Grimm, Wilhelm Carl

prev_sentence: The peasant made the raven croak again, and said: âIn the second place, he says that there is some roast meat in the tiled stove.â âUpon my word!â cried the miller, and went thither, and found the roast meat.
next_sentence: At last the peasant pinched the raven once more till he croaked, and said: âFourthly, he says that there are some cakes under the bed.â âThat would be a fine thing!â cried the miller, and looked there, and found the cakes.

question: Then he bought for the first two the fine clothes and pearls and diamonds they had asked for: and on his way home, as he rode through a [MASK] copse, a hazel twig brushed against him, and almost pushed off his hat: so he broke it off and brought it away; and when he got home he gave it to his daughter.

prev_sentence: âNow, child,â said he to his own daughter, âwhat will you have?â âThe first twig, dear father, that brushes against your hat when you turn your face to come homewards,â said she.
next_sentence: Then she took it, and went to her motherâs grave and planted it there; and cried so much that it was watered with her tears; and there it grew and became a fine tree.

question: In [MASK] of the cottage was a garden wherein stood two rose-trees, one of which bore white and the other red roses.

question: The [MASK] opened with difficulty, and the boy pinched his fingers.

title: Grimms' Fairy Tales

next_sentence: When it was open the wild man stepped out, gave him the golden ball, and hurried away.

question: The miser began to tell his [MASK], and said he had been robbed of his money.

question: He did all he could to soothe her, and she at last seemed to be appeased; but she was not so in [MASK], and was only thinking how she should punish him.

question: Then he ran after him with the [MASK] still in his hand, crying: âJust one, just one, â meaning that the guest should leave him just one chicken, and not take both.

question: Then the [MASK] sent out his officers to bring up the accused wherever they should find him; and he was soon caught and brought up to be tried.

question: He had not gone far before he met an old miser: close by them stood a tree, and on the topmost twig [MASK] a thrush singing away most joyfully.

question: The cook got up [MASK], before daybreak, to feed the cows; and going straight to the hay-loft, carried away a large bundle of hay, with the little man in the middle of it, fast asleep.

question: Then she took her clumsy shoe off her left foot, and put on the golden [MASK]; and it fitted her as if it had been made for her.

question: âBless me! â said the old woman, âhow badly your stays are [MASK]!

title: Grimms' Fairy Tales
prev_sentence: Then he sprang from the couch dreadfully frightened, ran to the well, filled a cup that was standing by him full of water, and hastened to get away in time.
next_sentence: When he found himself safe, he was overjoyed to think that he had got the Water of Life; and as he was going on his way homewards, he passed by the little dwarf, who, when he saw the sword and the loaf, said, âYou have made a noble prize; with the sword you can at a blow slay whole armies, and the bread will never fail you.â Then the prince thought to himself, âI cannot go home to my father without my brothersâ; so he said, âMy dear friend, cannot you tell me where my two brothers are, who set out in search of the Water of Life before me, and never came back?â âI have shut them up by a charm between two mountains,â said the dwarf, âbecause they were proud and ill-behaved, and scorned to ask advice.â The prince begged so hard for his brothers, that the dwarf at last set them free, though unwillingly, saying, âBeware of them, for they have bad hearts.â Their brother, however, was greatly rejoiced to see them, and told them all that had happened to him; how he had found the Water of Life, and had taken a cup full of it; and how he had set a beautiful princess free from a spell that bound her; and how she had engaged to wait a whole year, and then to marry him, and to give him the kingdom.

question: If it were a pig now--like that fat [MASK] you are driving along at his ease--one could do something with it; it would at any rate make sausages.â âWell, â said the butcher, âI donât like to say no, when one is asked to do a kind, neighbourly thing.

next_sentence: To please you I will change, and give you my fine fat pig for the cow.â âHeaven reward you for your kindness and self-denial!â said Hans, as he gave the butcher the cow; and taking the pig off the wheel-barrow, drove it away, holding it by the string that was tied to its leg.

question: When the smoke had circled about the [MASK], suddenly a little black dwarf stood before him, and said: âLord, what are your commands? â âWhat my commands are? â replied the soldier, quite astonished.
